For the purposes of this question, offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised detonations (see the fine print for definitions), but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes and peaceful nuclear explosions.
See also:
Will the New START nuclear arms control agreement be renewed until at least 5 February 2027?
Conditional on New START not being renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026, will there be a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US by 2035?
Fine Print
Detonations must occur less than 20 kilometers above the surface of the Earth in order to count as being on or over US/Russia territory.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins.
In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack. “In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack” (Barrett et al., 2013). “In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders” (Barrett et al., 2013).

metadata.background_info:
New START is a nuclear arms reduction treaty between the United States and the Russian Federation, which was signed on 8 April 2010. After its extension in 2021 it is expected to last until 5 February 2026.
We ask a pair of questions about the odds of a Russia-US nuclear exchange conditional on New START being renewed/replaced or conditional it not being renewed/replaced in hopes of shedding some light on the impact of the treaty. (But of course differences between forecasts on the two questions could also partly reflect the impact of "third variables" that influence both whether the treaty is renewed/replaced and whether a Russia-US nuclear exchange occurs.)

reasons: Both questions are related to national and international security, specifically focusing on catastrophic events that could have significant global impacts.

The prevention of a large-scale terrorist attack like 9/11 and the prevention of a nuclear exchange between major powers like the US and Russia are both critical concerns for policymakers, security experts, and the general public.
The renewal or replacement of the New START treaty could influence global security dynamics, potentially affecting the likelihood of both terrorist attacks and nuclear exchanges.

Understanding the interplay between these two questions could provide insights into the broader security environment and the effectiveness of international agreements in preventing large-scale violence.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is relevant and worth considering.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
R is indeed the logical conjunction of P and Q. R states that both (a) another 9/11 on U.S. soil will be prevented at least through 2030 and (b) conditional on New START being renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026, there will be no nuclear exchange between Russia and the US by 2035. This is a combination of the conditions described in P and Q.
Or reasoning:
R is true if either P or Q is true. P is about preventing a 9/11-scale terrorist attack on U.S. soil by 2030, and Q is about a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US by 2035, given New START is renewed or replaced by a similar treaty after February 2026. R combines both conditions, stating that it resolves positively if either a 9/11-scale terrorist attack occurs by 2030 or a nuclear exchange occurs by 2035 under the specified condition. Therefore, R is the logical disjunction of P and Q.

The question will resolve as ambiguous if two or more other countries accuse the US of performing a nuclear test explosion but there is no verification. Otherwise, this question will resolve negatively

P.title: Will the US conduct a nuclear test explosion before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively to verification of a nuclear explosion by the CTBTO, the UN, or if an official government statement from the US is issued confirming the test. The question will resolve as ambiguous if two or more other countries accuse the US of performing a nuclear test explosion but there is no verification. metadata.background_info:
Trinity was the first nuclear weapon test. The test was conducted above ground on July 16, 1945 on what is now known as the White Sands Missile Range. Since Trinity, over 2,000 nuclear tests have been conducted world wide.
The US has conducted over 1,000 nuclear tests. The final test to be conducted by the US, code-name Divder, took place on September 23, 1992. Soon after, Gearge H. W. Bush declared a moratorium on nuclear weapons testing. In 1996, the US signed the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty which bans any type of nuclear explosion. To date, the treaty has not been ratified by the appropriate countries (including the US) and has not yet entered into force.
The decision to end nuclear weapons testing has not been recommended by everyone. One of the core missions of the National Nuclear Security Administration is to "ensure the United States maintains a safe, secure, and reliable nuclear stockpile through the application of unparalleled science, technology, engineering, and manufacturing." This is largely accomplished through super computers. However, some argue that weapons tests are still needed to accomplish this mission.
More recently, there have been reports that the Trump administration has considered performing a nuclear test explosion in response to potential low-yield tests from Russia and China.

Q.title: Will any state test a nuclear weapon with yield above 30 MT by 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2030, there are reports of such a test by reputable sources

metadata.background_info:
This is one of several questions in this tournament focused on nuclear proliferation, force sizes, or yields. See here for a list of such questions and some discussion of these topics.
Whether any country has very high-yield nuclear weapons in its arsenal is relevant both for understanding the total risk posed by nuclear weapons and for understanding how to reduce that risk.

reasons: The US conducting a nuclear test explosion could signal a shift in global nuclear policy, potentially leading other states to follow suit, including testing high-yield nuclear weapons.
Both questions pertain to nuclear testing and proliferation, which are closely related topics in international security and policy.
A US nuclear test might provoke other states to demonstrate their nuclear capabilities, possibly leading to tests with higher yields.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is relevant and worth considering.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
R is the logical conjunction of P and Q because R will only resolve positively if both P and Q resolve positively. Specifically, R requires both the verification of a US nuclear test explosion and reports of a nuclear weapon test with a yield above 30 MT by any state, which are the exact conditions described in P and Q respectively.
Or reasoning:
R is the logical disjunction of P and Q because R will be true if either P or Q is true. Specifically, R will resolve positively if either the US conducts a nuclear test explosion (P) or any state tests a nuclear weapon with a yield above 30 MT (Q).

P.title: Will there be a 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution is by credible assessment of world GDP in constant US dollars (or other appropriately widely-accepted units).
This question will resolve positively if world output doubles in a period of 4 years or less before 2050. It resolves negatively otherwise, i.e. if the following related question resolves ambiguously:
[Will there be a complete 4 year interval in which world output doubles, before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/736/will-…

Q.title: If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations, will humanity's population be less than 400 million 50 years later?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, 50 years after the final detonation as part of the first nuclear conflict (before January 1, 2100) which involves >1,000 offensive nuclear detonations, humanity's population is below 400 million. This would include, but is not limited to, scenarios in which humanity is extinct. The resolution of this question is not affected by whether, 50 years after the final detonation, the population is stable, rising, or falling; it is only affected by whether it is below 400 million.
This question will resolve as Ambiguous if there is no nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations by January 1, 2100.
For the purposes of this question, "humans" will be considered members of a species who could typically reproduce with typical 2021 humans without medical assistance. In scenarios where this question would resolve positively given that definition, but there remain >400 million beings that at least one 2021 Metaculus moderator would consider "human" (possible examples: some human-like digital minds; some possible types of genetically altered humans), this question will instead resolve ambiguously. This is because it is debatable whether such scenarios should count as population collapses.
Fine Print
No attempt will be made to distinguish the effects of the nuclear conflict from the effects of other events. That is, even if it's mere coincidence that the population declines and/or that it remains low following the nuclear conflict, the question can still resolve positively.
We request that you forecast your true beliefs despite the fact that a Metaculus scores may be unlikely to be tracked or cared about if this question resolves positively, given that forecasts on this question may play a role in informing important decisions.

Resolution Criteria

metadata.background_info:
Related Questions on Metaculus:
Will there be a complete 4 year interval in which world output doubles, before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles?
Will there be a complete 4 year interval in which world output doubles, before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles?
As of 2018, it's taken about 16 years for the world economic output to double. So it might seem absurd to talk about it doubling in one or even four years. But there is a potential major change on the horizon: very advanced Artificial Intelligence.
An important consideration in how to approach the AI alignment problem is the speed of the takeoff from massively subhuman AI to massively superhuman AI. The effectiveness of capacity limitation, as well as the existence of fire alarms for AI safety, are heavily dependent on this, for example.
Paul Christiano suggests operationalising the takeoff speed in terms of economic growth. A slow takeoff is one where the economy doubles in four years before the first time it doubles in one year, and a fast takeoff is one where it does not. (See the same article for Christiano's list of arguments regarding fast vs. slow takeoff.)

metadata.background_info:
Related Questions on Metaculus:
If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations, will humanity be extinct within 50 years?
Nuclear GC to cause (near) extinction
Would we recover if population falls <400m?
Will humans go extinct by 2100?
Extinction if population falls <400 million?
For simplicity, we will consider two detonations to be part of the same nuclear conflict if they occur within 30 days of each other (regardless of who detonates the weapons, who their targets are, what their motivations are, etc.).

reasons: A nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations could have catastrophic effects on global infrastructure, economies, and populations, making it highly unlikely for world output to double in a 4-year interval before 2050.
The aftermath of such a nuclear conflict could lead to a significant decline in global productivity, making economic recovery and growth extremely challenging.
The potential for a nuclear conflict could influence global economic policies, defense spending, and international relations, which in turn could affect economic growth rates.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is relevant because a nuclear conflict of this magnitude would have profound implications for global economic growth and population dynamics.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
R is asking whether both P and Q will occur. Specifically, R is true if and only if both P (a 4-year interval in which world output doubles before 2050) and Q (if there's a nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations, humanity's population will be less than 400 million 50 years later) are true. This is a direct logical conjunction of P and Q.
Or reasoning:
R is the logical disjunction of P and Q because R will resolve positively if either P or Q resolves positively. P is about a 4-year interval in which world output doubles before 2050, and Q is about a nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations with humanity's population below 400 million 50 years later. R combines both conditions and will resolve positively if either condition is met.

P.title: Will a nuclear weapon be detonated as an act of war by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if there is any nuclear detonation as an act of war between January 1, 2020 and January 1, 2050. Resolution will be by credible media reports. The detonation must be deliberate; accidental, inadvertent, or testing/peaceful detonations will not qualify (see fine print). Attacks using strategic and tactical nuclear weapons are both sufficient to qualify.
[2021-11-23]: Edited to clarify the definition of "deliberate" detonations.
Fine Print
Barrett et al. 2013 defined terms to distinguish between causes of nuclear detonations:
In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders.
In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack.
In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack.

Q.title: Will the USA enter a second civil war before 2031?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if all of the following conditions are met before January 1, 2031:
The Insurrection Act is invoked.
While the Insurrection Act is invoked, there are at least 500 deaths in a 6 month period as a result of armed conflicts between US residents and a branch of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts between/among such branches.
All of these deaths occur in any US state(s) (including DC).
Fine Print
Any conflicts between the US military and the armed forces of another country will be excluded from consideration in this question. Conflicts between the US military and US residents, possibly supported by other nations with weapons or resources, will be included.
Conflicts between civilians and local police will not be included, unless there are active armed forces in the region providing mutual support.
Deaths are calculated among all of the states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. New states which are admitted shall be included, states which secede or are removed, will not be included. Suicides do not count towards the death count.

Deaths are calculated among all of the states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. New states which are admitted shall be included, states which secede or are removed, will not be included. Suicides do not count towards the death count.

Resolution Criteria

metadata.background_info:
In the last 75 years, two nuclear weapons have been detonated as an act of war; the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945, at the end of WWII. Despite tensions being high between the US and the USSR during the Cold War, and several close calls, there have been no additional nuclear weapons detonated as acts of war.
Currently, estimated nuclear weapon stockpiles are 15,000 warheads worldwide, mostly in the US and Russia, and there are eight or nine states that possess nuclear weapons (China, France, Russia, United Kingdom, United States, India, North Korea, Pakistan, and Israel which remains officially ambiguous). The use of these nuclear weapons could be catastrophic.

Q.title: Will the USA enter a second civil war before 2031?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if all of the following conditions are met before January 1, 2031:
The Insurrection Act is invoked.
While the Insurrection Act is invoked, there are at least 500 deaths in a 6 month period as a result of armed conflicts between US residents and a branch of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts between/among such branches.
All of these deaths occur in any US state(s) (including DC).
Fine Print
Any conflicts between the US military and the armed forces of another country will be excluded from consideration in this question. Conflicts between the US military and US residents, possibly supported by other nations with weapons or resources, will be included.
Conflicts between civilians and local police will not be included, unless there are active armed forces in the region providing mutual support.
Deaths are calculated among all of the states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. New states which are admitted shall be included, states which secede or are removed, will not be included. Suicides do not count towards the death count.

metadata.background_info: Although democracies are generally unlikely to enter civil war (see this list of civil wars for a rough overview), the United States faces a particularly unusual situation at the moment. The current COVID-19 pandemic, social protests, effects of social media platform manipulation, and the presidential election all have the potential to disrupt social cohesion and garner negative attitudes toward the government. See this related question for a shorter timeframe: Will the USA enter a second civil war before July 2021?

reasons: A nuclear detonation as an act of war could lead to significant geopolitical instability, which might increase the likelihood of internal conflicts, including civil wars.
If the USA were to enter a second civil war, it could weaken the country's ability to prevent or respond to international threats, potentially making a nuclear detonation more likely.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is relevant because both events could influence each other, making it a legitimate area of interest for forecasters.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
R is a conjunction of P and Q because R will resolve as Yes if and only if both P (a nuclear weapon is detonated as an act of war by 2050) and Q (the USA enters a second civil war before 2031) are true. The conditions in R explicitly require both events described in P and Q to occur.
Or reasoning:
R is the logical disjunction of P and Q because R will resolve as Yes if either P or Q resolves as Yes. P is about a nuclear weapon being detonated as an act of war by 2050, and Q is about the USA entering a second civil war before 2031. R combines both conditions and will resolve as Yes if either of these events occurs.

P.title: Conditional on New START being renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026, will there be a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US by 2035?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question conditions on the following (i.e., it resolves ambiguously if this condition isn't met): New START is renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026, according to credible reports such as the [Arms Control Association]. By replacement by another nuclear arms control agreement we mean a situation when there is an agreement after 2026 that both US and Russian officials describe as a successor to New START. No attempt will be made to determine whether the renewed or replacement treaty actually has very similar terms to New START.
This question resolves positively if that condition is met and there is a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US between this question opening and 2035, defined here as at least one offensive nuclear detonation by the US on or over Russian territory and/or at least one offensive nuclear detonation made by Russia on or over US territory.
A state (US or Russia) will be considered responsible for a nuclear detonation if either:
(a) The state openly admits such responsibility (in a statement made by the President, Prime Minister, Minister/Secretary of Defense, the US Ambassador to Russia (or vice versa), a top military executive or a similarly important official)
(b) Credible reports by multinational organizations conclude that the state was responsible
(c) There are credible reports claiming the state was responsible and the state does not deny it.
If the state changes its claims (e.g. first admitting responsibility for the attack and then denying it), priority will be given to independent reports.
For the purposes of this question, offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised detonations (see the fine print for definitions), but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes and peaceful nuclear explosions.
See also:
Will the New START nuclear arms control agreement be renewed until at least 5 February 2027?
Conditional on New START not being renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026, will there be a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US by 2035?
Fine Print
Detonations must occur less than 20 kilometers above the surface of the Earth in order to count as being on or over US/Russia territory.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins.
In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack. “In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack” (Barrett et al., 2013). “In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders” (Barrett et al., 2013).

Q.title: In 2029, will the US have 3,800 or fewer nuclear weapons?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The size of the US's nuclear weapons stockpile reached a peak in 1966 at around 30,000 warheads. Following the deescalation and the end of the Cold War, the number has substantially decreased. Kristensen and Korda (2019) estimate that the US maintains a deployed stockpile of nearly 3,800 warheads. The approximate breakdown is as follows:
1,750 warheads are currently deployed, of which
1,300 strategic warheads are deployed on ballistic missiles,
300 at strategic bomber bases in the United States,
150 tactical bombs are deployed at air bases in Europe.
2,050 are in storage as a so-called hedge against technical or geopolitical surprises.
It is possible that this trend will reverse in a period of nuclear rearmament, especially if world tensions get worse. The Trump Administration’s Nuclear Posture Review takes a confrontational tone, presenting an assertive posture that embraces “Great Power competition” and includes plans to expand the US' nuclear arsenal.
In 2029, will the US have 3,800 or fewer nuclear weapons?
This resolves positive if credible sources, such as the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists' Nuclear Notebook (such as this one for 2019) reports that the US held 3,800 (or fewer) nuclear warheads at any time in 2029. A similar credible source may be consulted if the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists in no longer active or publishing reports. For the purposes of question resolution, warheads that are retired and awaiting dismantlement will not be counted.
See also the related question, If the US does not pursue nuclear disarmament, how many nuclear warheads will it have in 2029?

P_and_Q.title: Given New START is renewed or replaced by a similar treaty after February 2026, will there be both a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US by 2035 and the US having 3,800 or fewer nuclear weapons in 2029?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question conditions on the following (i.e., it resolves ambiguously if this condition isn't met): New START is renewed or replaced by another similar treaty after February 2026, according to credible reports such as the [Arms Control Association]. By replacement by another nuclear arms control agreement we mean a situation when there is an agreement after 2026 that both US and Russian officials describe as a successor to New START. No attempt will be made to determine whether the renewed or replacement treaty actually has very similar terms to New START.

This question resolves positively if both of the following conditions are met:
1. There is a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US between this question opening and 2035, defined here as at least one offensive nuclear detonation by the US on or over Russian territory and/or at least one offensive nuclear detonation made by Russia on or over US territory.
2. Credible sources, such as the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists' Nuclear Notebook, report that the US held 3,800 (or fewer) nuclear warheads at any time in 2029. A similar credible source may be consulted if the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists is no longer active or publishing reports. For the purposes of question resolution, warheads that are retired and awaiting dismantlement will not be counted.

A state (US or Russia) will be considered responsible for a nuclear detonation if either:
(a) The state openly admits such responsibility (in a statement made by the President, Prime Minister, Minister/Secretary of Defense, the US Ambassador to Russia (or vice versa), a top military executive or a similarly important official)
(b) Credible reports by multinational organizations conclude that the state was responsible
(c) There are credible reports claiming the state was responsible and the state does not deny it.
If the state changes its claims (e.g. first admitting responsibility for the attack and then denying it), priority will be given to independent reports.

For the purposes of this question, offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised detonations (see the fine print for definitions), but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes and peaceful nuclear explosions.

Fine Print
Detonations must occur less than 20 kilometers above the surface of the Earth in order to count as being on or over US/Russia territory.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins.
In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack. “In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack” (Barrett et al., 2013). “In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders” (Barrett et al., 2013).

metadata.background_info:
New START is a nuclear arms reduction treaty between the United States and the Russian Federation, which was signed on 8 April 2010. After its extension in 2021 it is expected to last until 5 February 2026.
We ask a pair of questions about the odds of a Russia-US nuclear exchange conditional on New START being renewed/replaced or conditional it not being renewed/replaced in hopes of shedding some light on the impact of the treaty. (But of course differences between forecasts on the two questions could also partly reflect the impact of "third variables" that influence both whether the treaty is renewed/replaced and whether a Russia-US nuclear exchange occurs.)

Q.title: In 2029, will the US have 3,800 or fewer nuclear weapons?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The size of the US's nuclear weapons stockpile reached a peak in 1966 at around 30,000 warheads. Following the deescalation and the end of the Cold War, the number has substantially decreased. Kristensen and Korda (2019) estimate that the US maintains a deployed stockpile of nearly 3,800 warheads. The approximate breakdown is as follows:
1,750 warheads are currently deployed, of which
1,300 strategic warheads are deployed on ballistic missiles,
300 at strategic bomber bases in the United States,
150 tactical bombs are deployed at air bases in Europe.
2,050 are in storage as a so-called hedge against technical or geopolitical surprises.
It is possible that this trend will reverse in a period of nuclear rearmament, especially if world tensions get worse. The Trump Administration’s Nuclear Posture Review takes a confrontational tone, presenting an assertive posture that embraces “Great Power competition” and includes plans to expand the US' nuclear arsenal.
In 2029, will the US have 3,800 or fewer nuclear weapons?
This resolves positive if credible sources, such as the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists' Nuclear Notebook (such as this one for 2019) reports that the US held 3,800 (or fewer) nuclear warheads at any time in 2029. A similar credible source may be consulted if the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists in no longer active or publishing reports. For the purposes of question resolution, warheads that are retired and awaiting dismantlement will not be counted.
See also the related question, If the US does not pursue nuclear disarmament, how many nuclear warheads will it have in 2029?

reasons: The renewal or replacement of New START could influence the overall nuclear strategy and stockpile decisions of the US, potentially affecting the number of nuclear weapons the US maintains.
A renewed or replaced New START treaty might include provisions or lead to diplomatic conditions that either encourage or discourage the reduction of nuclear arsenals.

The likelihood of a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US could be influenced by the number of nuclear weapons each country possesses, as a larger arsenal might be seen as a deterrent or a provocation.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is relevant and worth considering.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
R is the logical conjunction of P and Q because R resolves positively if and only if both P and Q resolve positively. Specifically, R requires both a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US by 2035 (condition from P) and the US having 3,800 or fewer nuclear weapons in 2029 (condition from Q).
Or reasoning:
R is a logical disjunction of P and Q because R will be true if either P or Q is true. P is about a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US conditional on the renewal or replacement of New START, and Q is about the US having 3,800 or fewer nuclear weapons in 2029. R combines both conditions, stating that it will be true if either the nuclear exchange occurs (P) or the US has 3,800 or fewer nuclear weapons (Q).

P.title: If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, will the company have performed at least 1.5x as well as the global equities market over the prior 12-2 months?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question defines Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) in the same way as this Metaculus question.
If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves according to the following methodology:
Let t be the date when the AGI is publicly known, as determined by the above Metaculus question. Let C be the company that developed the AGI.
Calculate the total return (including dividends) of C's stock over the period from 12 months prior to t to one month prior to t, inclusive.[1]
Over the same period, calculate the total return of the FTSE Global All Cap Index, or a similar index if FTSE no longer exists.
Calculate the ratio of C's total return over this period to the total return of FTSE. If the ratio is 1.5 or greater, then this question resolves affirmatively. Otherwise, it resolves negatively.
If the first AGI is not developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves ambiguously.
[1] In the event that the market is closed on the start/end date, instead use the latest prior date on which the market is open. In the event that the date does not exist, use the latest prior date that exists. For example, if the AGI is developed on December 31, "one month prior" is considered to be November 30. If the market is closed on November 30, then use November 29 instead

Q.title: Will Sam Bankman-Fried be the richest person in the world by 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2050, Sam Bankman-Fried is the richest person in the world according to the Bloomberg Billionaire Index or Forbes' List of Billionaires. It is not necessary for Bankman-Fried to maintain this position for any length of time, so long as Bankman-Fried's estimate of wealth is accurate (not reported in error).
If both Bloomberg and Forbes do not regularly update and report this information during this period, Metaculus may select an alternative credible source at their discretion, or resolve as Ambiguous

reasons: The development of AGI by a publicly traded company could have significant economic implications, potentially leading to substantial stock market gains for the company involved. This could be of interest to investors and market analysts.

And reasoning:

P.title: Will any country's military expenditure exceed that of the United States before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The United States of America spends significantly more in absolute terms on its defense than any other country, and this has been the case since World War II. In 2017, US military spending accounted for some $610 billion, 35% of global military spending in that year.
Will any country spend more on its military / defense in a given year before (and including) 2030 than the United States spends in the same year?
Resolution should cite official budget figures from the United States and the other country in question. Resolves ambiguously if before a positive resolution results there ceases to be a country known as the United States.
Our comparison will use three-year average of exchange rates to smooth effects of transitory exchange rate fluctuations.

Q.title: Will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
There is said to be an "AI Sputnik moment" if ANY of the following come true before 2050,
A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system. Upon the announcement, their stock price skyrockets by over 100% compared to its previous value within 7 days, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock price is likely a result of the AI development.
News of an AI development triggers the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP nominal to give a public speech regarding the ramifications of this particular AI development, within two weeks of the initial news reports.
The Nasdaq Composite (which is currently heavily weighted towards companies in the information technology sector) rises over 30% in the course of a single week, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock prices is likely a result of the AI development.
The Google Trends monitor for artificial intelligence shows that interest in artificial intelligence rises by over 100% relative to of its previous value, compared to the week prior (using the resolution at 12 months, as currently displayed by the Google Trends widget). If Google Trends changes their functionality or methodology dramatically (as determined by Metaculus admins), then this condition can no longer trigger a positive resolution.
Practically all reliable media outlets are referring to an AI development as an AI Sputnik moment, as referring to the historical Sputnik 1 satellite
Fine Print
Google Trends index scores vary depending on the date and location from which a user checks the site. To reduce ambiguity, to trigger the Google Trends section of the resolution criteria:
At least two Metaculus administrators need to be able to see the >100% Google Trends increase, when checking from different locations.
The increase must remain >100% for at least four days to trigger a Yes resolution. For instance, if we first notice an increase of >100% on a Monday, we will check again on Friday. We will only resolve "Yes" if the reported increase for the weeks in question is >100% on both days we check, for both admins, and we have no evidence that it dropped below 100% at any point during those four days.

P_and_Q.title: Will any country's military expenditure exceed that of the United States before 2030 and will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
1. Will any country spend more on its military/defense in a given year before (and including) 2030 than the United States spends in the same year?
- The United States of America spends significantly more in absolute terms on its defense than any other country, and this has been the case since World War II. In 2017, US military spending accounted for some $610 billion, 35% of global military spending in that year.
- Resolution should cite official budget figures from the United States and the other country in question. Resolves ambiguously if before a positive resolution results there ceases to be a country known as the United States.
- Our comparison will use three-year average of exchange rates to smooth effects of transitory exchange rate fluctuations.

2. Will there be an "AI Sputnik moment" before 2050?
- There is said to be an "AI Sputnik moment" if ANY of the following come true before 2050:
  a. A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system. Upon the announcement, their stock price skyrockets by over 100% compared to its previous value within 7 days, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock price is likely a result of the AI development.
  b. News of an AI development triggers the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP nominal to give a public speech regarding the ramifications of this particular AI development, within two weeks of the initial news reports.
  c. The Nasdaq Composite (which is currently heavily weighted towards companies in the information technology sector) rises over 30% in the course of a single week, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock prices is likely a result of the AI development.
  d. The Google Trends monitor for artificial intelligence shows that interest in artificial intelligence rises by over 100% relative to its previous value, compared to the week prior (using the resolution at 12 months, as currently displayed by the Google Trends widget). If Google Trends changes their functionality or methodology dramatically (as determined by Metaculus admins), then this condition can no longer trigger a positive resolution.
  e. Practically all reliable media outlets are referring to an AI development as an AI Sputnik moment, as referring to the historical Sputnik 1 satellite.
- Fine Print:
  - Google Trends index scores vary depending on the date and location from which a user checks the site. To reduce ambiguity, to trigger the Google Trends section of the resolution criteria:
    - At least two Metaculus administrators need to be able to see the >100% Google Trends increase, when checking from different locations.
    - The increase must remain >100% for at least four days to trigger a Yes resolution. For instance, if we first notice an increase of >100% on a Monday, we will check again on Friday. We will only resolve "Yes" if the reported increase for the weeks in question is >100% on both days we check, for both admins, and we have no evidence that it dropped below 100% at any point during those four days.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Any country's military expenditure exceed that of the United States before 2030? (b) An AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
P_or_Q.body:
(a) Will any country spend more on its military/defense in a given year before (and including) 2030 than the United States spends in the same year?
Resolution Criteria: The United States of America spends significantly more in absolute terms on its defense than any other country, and this has been the case since World War II. In 2017, US military spending accounted for some $610 billion, 35% of global military spending in that year. Resolution should cite official budget figures from the United States and the other country in question. Resolves ambiguously if before a positive resolution results there ceases to be a country known as the United States. Our comparison will use three-year average of exchange rates to smooth effects of transitory exchange rate fluctuations.

(b) Will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
Resolution Criteria: There is said to be an "AI Sputnik moment" if ANY of the following come true before 2050,
- A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system. Upon the announcement, their stock price skyrockets by over 100% compared to its previous value within 7 days, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock price is likely a result of the AI development.
- News of an AI development triggers the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP nominal to give a public speech regarding the ramifications of this particular AI development, within two weeks of the initial news reports.
- The Nasdaq Composite (which is currently heavily weighted towards companies in the information technology sector) rises over 30% in the course of a single week, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock prices is likely a result of the AI development.
- The Google Trends monitor for artificial intelligence shows that interest in artificial intelligence rises by over 100% relative to its previous value, compared to the week prior (using the resolution at 12 months, as currently displayed by the Google Trends widget). If Google Trends changes their functionality or methodology dramatically (as determined by Metaculus admins), then this condition can no longer trigger a positive resolution.
- Practically all reliable media outlets are referring to an AI development as an AI Sputnik moment, as referring to the historical Sputnik 1 satellite.
Fine Print: Google Trends index scores vary depending on the date and location from which a user checks the site. To reduce ambiguity, to trigger the Google Trends section of the resolution criteria:
- At least two Metaculus administrators need to be able to see the >100% Google Trends increase, when checking from different locations.
- The increase must remain >100% for at least four days to trigger a Yes resolution. For instance, if we first notice an increase of >100% on a Monday, we will check again on Friday. We will only resolve "Yes" if the reported increase for the weeks in question is >100% on both days we check, for both admins, and we have no evidence that it dropped below 100% at any point during those four days.

Q.title: Will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
There is said to be an "AI Sputnik moment" if ANY of the following come true before 2050,
A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system. Upon the announcement, their stock price skyrockets by over 100% compared to its previous value within 7 days, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock price is likely a result of the AI development.
News of an AI development triggers the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP nominal to give a public speech regarding the ramifications of this particular AI development, within two weeks of the initial news reports.
The Nasdaq Composite (which is currently heavily weighted towards companies in the information technology sector) rises over 30% in the course of a single week, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock prices is likely a result of the AI development.
The Google Trends monitor for artificial intelligence shows that interest in artificial intelligence rises by over 100% relative to of its previous value, compared to the week prior (using the resolution at 12 months, as currently displayed by the Google Trends widget). If Google Trends changes their functionality or methodology dramatically (as determined by Metaculus admins), then this condition can no longer trigger a positive resolution.
Practically all reliable media outlets are referring to an AI development as an AI Sputnik moment, as referring to the historical Sputnik 1 satellite
Fine Print
Google Trends index scores vary depending on the date and location from which a user checks the site. To reduce ambiguity, to trigger the Google Trends section of the resolution criteria:
At least two Metaculus administrators need to be able to see the >100% Google Trends increase, when checking from different locations.
The increase must remain >100% for at least four days to trigger a Yes resolution. For instance, if we first notice an increase of >100% on a Monday, we will check again on Friday. We will only resolve "Yes" if the reported increase for the weeks in question is >100% on both days we check, for both admins, and we have no evidence that it dropped below 100% at any point during those four days.

metadata.background_info:
From Wikipedia,
Sputnik 1 was the first artificial Earth satellite. It was launched into an elliptical low Earth orbit by the USSR on 4 October 1957 as part of the Soviet space program. It orbited for three weeks before its batteries died and then orbited silently for two months before it fell back into the atmosphere on the 4th January 1958.
[...]
The satellite's unanticipated success precipitated the American Sputnik crisis and triggered the Space Race, part of the Cold War. The launch was the beginning of a new era of political, military, technological and scientific developments.
An "AI Sputnik moment" would, by contrast, be a sudden understanding by the general public that artificial intelligence is worth taking extremely seriously, perhaps triggering a similar AI arms race.

reasons: A significant increase in military expenditure by a country could be driven by advancements in AI technology, which might be perceived as a strategic advantage. This could lead to an AI Sputnik moment, where the development of AI is seen as a game-changer in military capabilities.
An AI Sputnik moment could lead to increased investments in AI and defense technologies, potentially causing a country to ramp up its military spending to surpass the United States.

Both questions involve significant geopolitical and technological shifts, which could be interrelated. For instance, a breakthrough in AI could lead to a new arms race, influencing military expenditures.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is worth considering due to the potential interrelation between advancements in AI and changes in military expenditure.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
R is the logical conjunction of P and Q because R is true if and only if both P and Q are true. Specifically, R requires both that a country's military expenditure exceeds that of the United States before 2030 (P) and that there is an AI Sputnik moment before 2050 (Q).
Or reasoning:
R is a logical disjunction of P and Q because R will be true if either P or Q is true. P is about any country's military expenditure exceeding that of the United States before 2030, and Q is about an AI Sputnik moment before 2050. R combines both conditions, stating that it will be true if either of these events occurs.

P.title: If there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2030, in which countries will there be at least one fatality? (North Korea)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occuring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occuring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
For this question, an "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations of by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).
Fine Print
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

Q.title: Will armed conflict between the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China (PRC) cause at least 100 deaths before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2050, either of the following occurs:
There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of Taiwan and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period.
This question will resolve as No otherwise.
In the context of this question, an armed conflict will be defined as a dispute that concerns a government and/or territory where the use of armed force between two parties, of which at least one is the government of a state, results in an exchange of weapon fire or detonations

There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths. These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period. This part will resolve as No otherwise. In the context of this part, an armed conflict will be defined as a dispute that concerns a government and/or territory where the use of armed force between two parties, of which at least one is the government of a state, results in an exchange of weapon fire or detonations.

Q.title: Will armed conflict between the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China (PRC) cause at least 100 deaths before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2050, either of the following occurs:
There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of Taiwan and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period.
This question will resolve as No otherwise.
In the context of this question, an armed conflict will be defined as a dispute that concerns a government and/or territory where the use of armed force between two parties, of which at least one is the government of a state, results in an exchange of weapon fire or detonations

metadata.background_info: 2049 marks the 100th anniversary of the People's Republic of China. Graham Allison and The Brookings Institute have suggested that the PRC wants to achieve some form of national greatness by 2049, which would possibly include conquering Taiwan.

reasons: A nuclear detonation could significantly alter geopolitical dynamics, potentially influencing the likelihood of armed conflict between Taiwan and the PRC.
The occurrence of a nuclear detonation might lead to heightened military alertness and tensions in the region, which could escalate into armed conflict.
Both questions involve significant geopolitical events that could have cascading effects on international relations and security.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is worth considering due to the potential interconnectedness of major geopolitical events and their impact on global security.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
The event described in R is the conjunction of the events described in P and Q. Specifically, R requires both (1) at least one fatality in North Korea from an offensive nuclear detonation by 2030 (which is the event described in P) and (2) armed conflict between Taiwan and the PRC causing at least 100 deaths before 2050 (which is the event described in Q). Therefore, R is true if and only if both P and Q are true.
Or reasoning:
R is a logical disjunction of P and Q because R will be true if either P or Q is true. P is about fatalities in North Korea due to an offensive nuclear detonation by 2030, and Q is about deaths due to armed conflict between Taiwan and the People's Republic of China by 2050. R combines both conditions, stating that it will be true if either there is at least one fatality in North Korea due to an offensive nuclear detonation by 2030 or there are at least 100 deaths due to armed conflict between Taiwan and the People's Republic of China by 2050.

P.title: Will there be at least one fatality in the US from a non-test nuclear detonation by 2050 if a non-test detonation causes a fatality anywhere?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if an offensive nuclear detonation occurs at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2050 and causes at least one fatality in the US. This question will resolve as ambiguous if there are no offensive nuclear detonations in that time period. Detonations for testing purposes, peaceful nuclear explosions, and accidental detonations of a state's weapon on its own territory will not count towards question resolution, even if such detonations cause substantial damage. Detonations by either state or non-state actors can count towards question resolution.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation, so a fatality caused by things like fallout, rioting, or climate effects will not count towards a positive resolution.
For the purposes of this question, the "United States" will be defined as any and all of the US states (excluding, for example, overseas territories such as Guam).
Fine Print
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to the resolution council or Metaculus admins.

Q.title: Will any country have a nuclear weapon with yield above 30 MT by 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if, at any time between November 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030, the following two conditions are met:
At least two credible sources (major governments, scientific associations, or intelligence services) claim that a country most likely has a nuclear weapon with a yield above 30 MT. This weapon may be stockpiled or deployed (but not in development, for example).
No two independent credible sources with ability to evaluate such a claim contest / deny this claim. Media reports will be counted only to the extent that they reference to such a credible source; news organizations themselves cannot be expected to have means of evaluating such a claim on their own. In the case that there is significant disagreement between these claims Metaculus Admins may, at their discretion, make a judgement about the credibility of these claims, or resolve ambiguously.
The Russian Poseidon/Status-6 device, for example, could resolve this question positively if it met these two conditions.
This question can resolve positively even if the country has only one such weapon, and even if it has such a weapon sometime before 2030 but no longer has such a weapon on January 1, 2030 (e.g., if it test detonates, offensively detonates, or dismantles the weapon before then)

metadata.background_info: Nuclear weapons have only been detonated offensively twice. Both detonations were by the US over Japanese cities in 1945. As of May 2021, the US and two of its strategic rivals are the states with the most nuclear warheads in the world (Russia with 6,257, the US with 5,550, and China with 350).

Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if, at any time between November 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030, the following two conditions are met:
At least two credible sources (major governments, scientific associations, or intelligence services) claim that a country most likely has a nuclear weapon with a yield above 30 MT. This weapon may be stockpiled or deployed (but not in development, for example).
No two independent credible sources with ability to evaluate such a claim contest / deny this claim. Media reports will be counted only to the extent that they reference to such a credible source; news organizations themselves cannot be expected to have means of evaluating such a claim on their own. In the case that there is significant disagreement between these claims Metaculus Admins may, at their discretion, make a judgement about the credibility of these claims, or resolve ambiguously.
The Russian Poseidon/Status-6 device, for example, could resolve this question positively if it met these two conditions.
This question can resolve positively even if the country has only one such weapon, and even if it has such a weapon sometime before 2030 but no longer has such a weapon on January 1, 2030 (e.g., if it test detonates, offensively detonates, or dismantles the weapon before then)

metadata.background_info:
This is one of several questions in this tournament focused on nuclear proliferation, force sizes, or yields. See here for a list of such questions and some discussion of these topics.
Whether any country has very high-yield nuclear weapons in its arsenal is relevant both for understanding the total risk posed by nuclear weapons and for understanding how to reduce that risk.

reasons: A country developing a nuclear weapon with a yield above 30 MT could indicate an escalation in nuclear arms development, which might increase the likelihood of nuclear conflict and thus the probability of a nuclear detonation causing fatalities in the US.
The development of such high-yield nuclear weapons could lead to changes in international relations and defense strategies, potentially influencing the likelihood of nuclear attacks on the US.
If a country possesses a nuclear weapon with a yield above 30 MT, it might embolden that country or its allies to take more aggressive actions, increasing the risk of nuclear conflict.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is relevant because the development of high-yield nuclear weapons could influence the likelihood of nuclear conflict and fatalities in the US.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
R is the logical conjunction of P and Q because R will resolve as Yes if and only if both P and Q resolve as Yes. Specifically, R requires both (a) a non-test nuclear detonation causing at least one fatality in the US by 2050 (which is the same as P) and (b) any country having a nuclear weapon with yield above 30 MT by 2030 (which is the same as Q).
Or reasoning:
R is the logical disjunction of P and Q because R will resolve as Yes if either P or Q resolves as Yes. P is about a non-test nuclear detonation causing a fatality in the US by 2050, and Q is about any country having a nuclear weapon with a yield above 30 MT by 2030. R combines both conditions, stating that it will resolve as Yes if either of these events occurs.

P.title: Will there be a global thermonuclear war by 2070?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if there is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true:
Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory
Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
These conditions are chosen to set aside a two-party regional nuclear war, say between India and Pakistan, or Israel and an adversary, or the UK and France, as disastrous as that would be.
As with many questions with a positive-resolution condition that may preclude being awarded points on Metaculus, predictors are enjoined to predict in good faith, as points will not be awarded until 2070 anyway

Q.title: Before 2070, Will there be a civil war in a country that, in January 2022, had a median age above 30?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Related Questions on Metaculus:
Will a civil war break out in a country with median age above 30 before 2070?
Will the USA enter a second civil war before 2031?
There is a large variation in the median age of countries. Some have suggested that a youth bulge makes civil war more likely. Syria, Afghanistan, Libya, and Iraq have median ages at most 30 and experienced civil wars recently, as does virtually all of sub-Saharan Africa which has experienced civil wars. Sri Lanka's median age passed 30 right around the time the Sri Lankan Civil War ended. Younger populations are associated with an increased risk of civil war.
Before 2070, Will there be a civil war in a country that, in January 2020, had a median age above 30?
This question will resolve positively if before January 1, 2070, at least two of the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, the Economist, the Guardian, and the Spectator indicate that a civil war begins in a country that has a median age is 30.1 or above according to the 2020 figures from both the CIA World Factbook and the United Nations.. A copy of this data is available here.
In the case of political or territorial changes of any nation on the list, the successor country will be identified as having the same political capitol as the parent country.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be both a global thermonuclear war and a civil war in a country with a median age above 30 before 2070?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following occur before January 1, 2070:
(a) There is an armed conflict where either of the following conditions are true:
- Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory
- Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
(b) At least two of the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, the Economist, the Guardian, and the Spectator indicate that a civil war begins in a country that had a median age of 30.1 or above in January 2020 according to the CIA World Factbook and the United Nations.
In the case of political or territorial changes of any nation on the list, the successor country will be identified as having the same political capital as the parent country.
These conditions are chosen to set aside a two-party regional nuclear war, say between India and Pakistan, or Israel and an adversary, or the UK and France, as disastrous as that would be.
As with many questions with a positive-resolution condition that may preclude being awarded points on Metaculus, predictors are enjoined to predict in good faith, as points will not be awarded until 2070 anyway.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur before 2070: (a) a global thermonuclear war or (b) a civil war in a country that had a median age above 30 in January 2022?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if either of the following conditions are met before January 1, 2070:

(a) A global thermonuclear war occurs, defined as an armed conflict where either of the following conditions are true:
- Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
- Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
These conditions are chosen to set aside a two-party regional nuclear war, say between India and Pakistan, or Israel and an adversary, or the UK and France, as disastrous as that would be.

(b) A civil war begins in a country that had a median age above 30 in January 2022, as indicated by at least two of the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, the Economist, the Guardian, and the Spectator. The median age must be 30.1 or above according to the 2020 figures from both the CIA World Factbook and the United Nations. A copy of this data is available here. In the case of political or territorial changes of any nation on the list, the successor country will be identified as having the same political capital as the parent country.

Related Questions on Metaculus:
- Will a civil war break out in a country with a median age above 30 before 2070?
- Will the USA enter a second civil war before 2031?

As with many questions with a positive-resolution condition that may preclude being awarded points on Metaculus, predictors are enjoined to predict in good faith, as points will not be awarded until 2070 anyway.

P.title: Will there be a global thermonuclear war by 2070?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if there is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true:
Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory
Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
These conditions are chosen to set aside a two-party regional nuclear war, say between India and Pakistan, or Israel and an adversary, or the UK and France, as disastrous as that would be.
As with many questions with a positive-resolution condition that may preclude being awarded points on Metaculus, predictors are enjoined to predict in good faith, as points will not be awarded until 2070 anyway

metadata.background_info:
Weapons in which the energy is provided by nuclear fission or fusion have only twice in history been detonated outside of a controlled test environment, in the Hiroshima and Nagasaki events in World War II.
Since then, the world has nearly gone to nuclear war as a result of international conflict (during the Cuban Missile Crisis) and by accident. (Indeed, there have been a number of narrowly-averted accidental nuclear detonations. See this timeline for a sobering look at how close we have come.)
This question (which any sane person will hope resolves negatively) regards the probability that a nuclear war will occur by Jan 1, 2070. (Different questions address this separately, but none directly.) There is a great paucity of public and useful estimates of this probability. See for example this paper for an outline of considerations (but no bottom-line numbers.)

Q.title: Before 2070, Will there be a civil war in a country that, in January 2022, had a median age above 30?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Related Questions on Metaculus:
Will a civil war break out in a country with median age above 30 before 2070?
Will the USA enter a second civil war before 2031?
There is a large variation in the median age of countries. Some have suggested that a youth bulge makes civil war more likely. Syria, Afghanistan, Libya, and Iraq have median ages at most 30 and experienced civil wars recently, as does virtually all of sub-Saharan Africa which has experienced civil wars. Sri Lanka's median age passed 30 right around the time the Sri Lankan Civil War ended. Younger populations are associated with an increased risk of civil war.
Before 2070, Will there be a civil war in a country that, in January 2020, had a median age above 30?
This question will resolve positively if before January 1, 2070, at least two of the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, the Economist, the Guardian, and the Spectator indicate that a civil war begins in a country that has a median age is 30.1 or above according to the 2020 figures from both the CIA World Factbook and the United Nations.. A copy of this data is available here.
In the case of political or territorial changes of any nation on the list, the successor country will be identified as having the same political capitol as the parent country.

reasons: A civil war in a country with a median age above 30 could destabilize international relations and increase the likelihood of global conflicts, including a thermonuclear war.

Countries with higher median ages are often more developed and have significant geopolitical influence. A civil war in such a country could have far-reaching consequences, potentially escalating into larger conflicts.
Understanding the correlation between civil wars in more developed countries and the risk of global thermonuclear war could be valuable for policymakers and researchers studying conflict prevention.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is worth considering as it explores the potential link between civil wars in more developed countries and the risk of global thermonuclear war.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
R is the logical conjunction of P and Q because R will resolve as Yes if and only if both P and Q resolve as Yes. Specifically, R requires both a global thermonuclear war (as defined in P) and a civil war in a country with a median age above 30 (as defined in Q) to occur before 2070.
Or reasoning:
R is the logical disjunction of P and Q because R will resolve as Yes if either P or Q resolves as Yes. Specifically, R will resolve as Yes if either a global thermonuclear war occurs (which is the condition for P) or a civil war occurs in a country with a median age above 30 in January 2022 (which is the condition for Q).

P.title: Who will be the Democratic nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Joe Biden)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the candidate below who is selected by the Democratic National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates not selected by the DNC will resolve as No, for whatever reason (if they are deceased, choose not to seek nomination, withdraw candidacy, are not selected by delegates, or any other reason). This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.
For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Democratic nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Democratic National Convention.
Fine Print
If there is no Democratic National Convention convened in the year 2024, or that convention does not select a nominee, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.

Q.title: Will there be a US-China war before 2035?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
For the purposes of this question, a US-China war is defined as the US and China collectively suffering at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between the US and an ally of China or between China and an ally of the US will not count towards positive resolution. If this does not occur before January 1, 2035, this question will resolve negatively.
We here define battle related deaths as defined by the Uppsala University Department of Peace and Conflict Studies.
Resolution will come from reputable news sources, from official federal or military announcements, or from multinational institutions like the UN or NATO

P_and_Q.title: Will Joe Biden be the Democratic nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election and will there be a US-China war before 2035?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following occur: (1) Joe Biden is selected by the Democratic National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (2) the US and China collectively suffer at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year before January 1, 2035, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources.

For the first part, it is not relevant who receives the Democratic nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Democratic National Convention. If there is no Democratic National Convention convened in the year 2024, or that convention does not select a nominee, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.

For the second part, deaths in battles fought between the US and an ally of China or between China and an ally of the US will not count towards positive resolution. Battle-related deaths are defined by the Uppsala University Department of Peace and Conflict Studies. Resolution will come from reputable news sources, from official federal or military announcements, or from multinational institutions like the UN or NATO.

P.body:
