Q.title: Will the United States Environmental Protection Agency pass a PFAS Maximum Contaminant Level rule for all municipal water systems in the United States by January 1, 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the United States Federal Register lists a MCL rule for PFAS in for all sizes of public drinking water systems in the United States by January 1, 2030

metadata.background_info:
PFAS were first developed in the 1940s by DuPont. By the 1950s, 3M began manufacturing various PFAS (including PFOA and PFOS) for consumer and commercial product applications (including Scotchguard and Teflon). Currently many products are still manufactured that contain PFAS including everything from food containers to firefighting foam to non-stick cookware.
PFAS can cause multiple detrimental effects including but not limited to reproductive & developmental problems, liver & kidney damage, tumors and immunological effects in laboratory animals. The most consistent findings are increased cholesterol levels among exposed populations.
Studies have shown PFAS to be in the blood serum samples of nearly everyone human tested, every body of water, rain, snow, and even bottled water - all which indicate widespread human exposure.
As of September 18, 2020, the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) “ToxCast Chemical Inventory” stated that there are 430 different chemicals in the PFAS group. The EPA collected data on six Perfluorinated Compounds Third Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Rule yet has not proposed any Maximum Contaminant Level (MCL) standards since the UCMR3 study.

reasons: The financial stability of major corporations can be influenced by regulatory changes, including environmental regulations. If the EPA passes stringent PFAS regulations, it could lead to increased operational costs for companies that are heavily reliant on water usage or have significant environmental footprints, potentially pushing them towards financial distress or bankruptcy.

Investors and policymakers might be interested in understanding the interplay between environmental regulations and corporate financial health. This could inform decisions on regulatory policies and investment strategies.
relevance.conclusion: There is a plausible connection between the two questions, as environmental regulations can impact the financial stability of major corporations.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
R is a conjunction of P and Q because it requires both conditions to be met: (1) one of the 20 most valuable public companies in the United States as of January 2019 must file for bankruptcy protection before 2025, and (2) the United States Environmental Protection Agency must pass a PFAS Maximum Contaminant Level rule for all municipal water systems in the United States by January 1, 2030. Both conditions must be true for R to be true, which aligns with the logical conjunction of P and Q.
Or reasoning:
R is a logical disjunction of P and Q because it will be true if either P or Q is true. P asks about the bankruptcy of the 20 most valuable public companies in the US before 2025, and Q asks about the EPA passing a PFAS Maximum Contaminant Level rule by 2030. R combines both conditions, stating that it will be true if either of these events occurs.

P.title: Will the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Related Questions on Metaculus:
Will the USD fraction of allocated global foreign exchange currencies be below 50% before the following years?
What will be the United States Dollar's percentage of all currency reserves, as of Q1 2050?
The IMF regularly publishes information on the composition of official global foreign exchange reserves in the aggregated Currency Composition of Foreign Exchange Reserves (COFER). As of Q3 2019, the U.S dollar comprises 61.8% of the total (source).
Several contributing factors are thought to contribute to this state of affairs, including the stability, size, and liquidity of United States Treasury assets, the tying of other currencies to the U.S dollar as part of the Bretton Woods Agreement, and the strength of the U.S economy.
At present, the U.S dollar is considered to be the world's dominant reserve currency. This is considered to diminish the impact of higher U.S trade deficits and allowing it to impose unilateral sanctions. However, it has been speculated that the U.S dollar may be supplanted by the euro or the renminbi, or may diminish in importance.
Will the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050?
Question resolves positively if the most recently released percentage of allocated global foreign currency reserves comprising of the U.S dollar, by year-end 2050, is over 50%. Per moderator discretion, if the IMF has ceased publication of COFER in lieu of a new publication containing the same statistics, the new publication will be used instead.
Question resolves as ambiguous the IMF has not published any statistics for any quarters after Q1 2045, if admins judge that the IMF has ceased to exist.

Q.title: Will North Korea and South Korea be recognized as a unified sovereign state by 2045?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
All of Korea had been unified as a single state for centuries. After World War II and beginning in the Cold War, Korea was divided into two countries along the 38th parallel (now the Korean Demilitarized Zone). In 1950, North Korea invaded the South, beginning the Korean War, which ended in stalemate in 1953.
Even after the end of the Korean War, reunification proved a challenge as the two countries became increasingly diverged at a steady pace. However, in the late 2010s, relations between North and South Korea warmed somewhat, beginning with North Korea's participation at the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea. In 2019, South Korean president Moon Jae-in proposed reunification of the two divided states in the Korean peninsula by 2045.
Will North Korea and South Korea be recognized as a single sovereign state by 2045?
The question resolves positively if either:
North Korea and South Korea (or their respective descendants if they change name) merge.
or
North Korea, South Korea or both (or their respective descendants if they change name) stop existing, and an entity (possibly the one that's left) controls 90%+ of the current North Korea + South Korea landmass and has its capital on that territory.
Resolution will be by reputable source that either has happened, as judged by Metaculus mods/admins.

P_and_Q.title: Will the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050 and will North Korea and South Korea be recognized as a unified sovereign state by 2045?
P_and_Q.body:

Per moderator discretion, if the IMF has ceased publication of COFER in lieu of a new publication containing the same statistics, the new publication will be used instead.
- The question resolves as ambiguous if the IMF has not published any statistics for any quarters after Q1 2045, if admins judge that the IMF has ceased to exist.

2. Will North Korea and South Korea be recognized as a unified sovereign state by 2045?
- The question resolves positively if either:
  a. North Korea and South Korea (or their respective descendants if they change name) merge.
  b. North Korea, South Korea or both (or their respective descendants if they change name) stop existing, and an entity (possibly the one that's left) controls 90%+ of the current North Korea + South Korea landmass and has its capital on that territory.
- Resolution will be by reputable source that either has happened, as judged by Metaculus mods/admins.

Both conditions must be met for this question to resolve positively.

reasons: Geopolitical Stability: The unification of North and South Korea could have significant implications for global geopolitical stability. A unified Korea might influence global economic policies, which in turn could affect the dominance of the USD as a global reserve currency.

relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, particularly from a geopolitical and economic perspective.

P.title: Will there be an breakaway European Soccer League match before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
On April 18, 2021, 12 top European football clubs agreed to join the European Super League, a breakaway league separate from the usual organizational structure of association football.
It received a great deal of backlash from stakeholders:
Gary Neville is disgusted
Gary Linekar is disgusted
Boris Johnson promises "to make sure the goverment does everything it can to make sure it doesn't go ahead"
On the other hand, publicly traded football clubs (Manchester United, Juventus) have seen their share prices soar as this is generally forecasted as being extremely lucrative for the clubs involved.
Whilst it appears that the ESL is dead in the water, the clubs involved have all pulled back, there is still a lot of speculation as to whether a breakaway league will still happen given the financial incentives.
Will there be an breakaway European soccer League match before 2030?
Any association football matches played under the structure of a breakaway group unrelated to the usual structure of football in Europe, which features at least 5 of the following big clubs, and teams from at least 3 UEFA countries (not all countries need to be from this list, 5 teams from this list from 2 countries and an additional team from a 3rd country would be acceptable):
Arsenal FC
Chelsea FC
Liverpool FC
Manchester City FC
Manchester United FC
Tottenham Hotspur FC
Inter Milan
Juventus FC
AC Milan
Atlético Madrid
FC Barcelona
Real Madrid CF
Bayern Munich
Borussia Dortmund
Bayer Leverkusen
Schalke 04
PSG
Lyon
Ajax

Q.title: Will the UK have a Labour Prime Minister on January 1, 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the UK Prime Minister on January 1, 2030 is a member of the Labour Party.
Otherwise, the question resolves negatively.
Fine Print
If, in 2030, the United Kingdom does not exist in its 2020 form, then the question resolves as the Prime Minister of the country containing London.
If the Labour party is simply renamed, this question applies to the new party.
In case the Labour party does not continue in its current form, this question also resolves positively if the following three conditions are all met at 2030-1-1 00:00 GMT:
The UK Prime Minister is a member of a political party that did not exist on 2021-01-01,
The UK Prime Minister is former member of the Labour party, and
Fewer than 20% of MPs belong to the Labour Party.
If, at 2030-1-1 00:00 GMT, there is no such Prime Minister, the question resolves ambiguously.

metadata.background_info:

Will the UK have a Conservative Prime Minister on January 1, 2030?
The Labour Party is a centre-left political party in the United Kingdom that has been described as an alliance of social democrats, democratic socialists and trade unionists. The party's platform emphasises greater state intervention, social justice and strengthening workers' rights. As of 2020, it was last in power from 1997 to 2010.

reasons: Political climate and government policies can have a significant impact on sports regulations and the financial environment in which sports organizations operate. A Labour Prime Minister might have different policies regarding sports and business regulations compared to a Conservative Prime Minister, which could influence the feasibility of a breakaway European Soccer League.

The Labour Party has historically had different stances on issues like corporate governance, taxation, and international relations compared to the Conservative Party. These differences could affect the financial incentives and regulatory environment for football clubs considering a breakaway league.

P.title: Will the next US presidential election also be considered fraudulent by the losing party?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For the purpose of this question, the "losing party" is defined as the party whose presidential candidate is projected to come in second place in the electoral college vote count by both the AP and Fox News (see fine print). This question resolves positively if ANY of the following come true following the 2024 presidential election,
The losing candidate states that they consider the election result "fraudulent" or "rigged", or some very close synonym of those words, as determined by consensus in the comment section of this question. The losing candidate must make this claim before the scheduled inauguration. If there is a dispute as to whether the candidate did indeed say a close synonym of "fraudulent" or "rigged", and therefore a dispute over whether the word choice counts for positive resolution, then the following method of resolution will be used: if thesaurus.com lists "fraud", "fraudulent", or "rigged" as a synonym of the word, and at least one moderator agrees that it is a close synonym, then it counts for positive resolution.
The losing candidate refuses to concede two weeks following both the AP and Fox News projecting their opponent to win the election AND neither the AP or Fox News having retracted their projection in that time. For the purpose of this question, a concession is a clear statement from the candidate projected to lose that they have acknowledged their defeat, and that they accept the results of the election. The concession must not be retracted within 48 hours.
Fewer than 20% of congressional members of the losing party believe that their candidate lost the election as determined by credible media two weeks following both the AP and Fox News projecting the opposite-party candidate to win the election AND neither the AP or Fox News having retracted their projection in that time. By comparison, on December 7th 2020, just 27 congressional Republicans acknowledge Biden’s win according to the Washington Post.
A survey from the Morning Consult reveals that fewer than 30% of survey participants who are members of the losing party state that the election was "probably" or "definitely" free and fair in the most recent such survey following projections from both the AP and Fox News. The relevant survey for 2020 can be found here.
Otherwise, the question resolves negatively.
Fine Print
For the purpose of this question, a network is said to have "projected" a winner if they make some authoritative statement saying that the candidate has won the election, or will win the election once the votes are counted. Crucially, the network does not actually have to use the language of "projected" but as long as their reporting follows this definition, it counts as a projection.

Q.title: Will there be fewer than 6 conservative justices on the SCOTUS on January 20, 2025?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if on January 20, 2025, at noon EST, there are fewer than 6 conservative justices on the Supreme Court of the United States, as per reliable sources

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) The next US presidential election will be considered fraudulent by the losing party (b) There will be fewer than 6 conservative justices on the SCOTUS on January 20, 2025?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
(a) For the purpose of this question, the "losing party" is defined as the party whose presidential candidate is projected to come in second place in the electoral college vote count by both the AP and Fox News (see fine print). This question resolves positively if ANY of the following come true following the 2024 presidential election:
- The losing candidate states that they consider the election result "fraudulent" or "rigged", or some very close synonym of those words, as determined by consensus in the comment section of this question. The losing candidate must make this claim before the scheduled inauguration. If there is a dispute as to whether the candidate did indeed say a close synonym of "fraudulent" or "rigged", and therefore a dispute over whether the word choice counts for positive resolution, then the following method of resolution will be used: if thesaurus.com lists "fraud", "fraudulent", or "rigged" as a synonym of the word, and at least one moderator agrees that it is a close synonym, then it counts for positive resolution.
- The losing candidate refuses to concede two weeks following both the AP and Fox News projecting their opponent to win the election AND neither the AP or Fox News having retracted their projection in that time. For the purpose of this question, a concession is a clear statement from the candidate projected to lose that they have acknowledged their defeat, and that they accept the results of the election. The concession must not be retracted within 48 hours.
- Fewer than 20% of congressional members of the losing party believe that their candidate lost the election as determined by credible media two weeks following both the AP and Fox News projecting the opposite-party candidate to win the election AND neither the AP or Fox News having retracted their projection in that time. By comparison, on December 7th 2020, just 27 congressional Republicans acknowledge Biden’s win according to the Washington Post.
- A survey from the Morning Consult reveals that fewer than 30% of survey participants who are members of the losing party state that the election was "probably" or "definitely" free and fair in the most recent such survey following projections from both the AP and Fox News. The relevant survey for 2020 can be found here.
Otherwise, the question resolves negatively.
Fine Print
For the purpose of this question, a network is said to have "projected" a winner if they make some authoritative statement saying that the candidate has won the election, or will win the election once the votes are counted. Crucially, the network does not actually have to use the language of "projected" but as long as their reporting follows this definition, it counts as a projection.
(b) This question will resolve as Yes if on January 20, 2025, at noon EST, there are fewer than 6 conservative justices on the Supreme Court of the United States, as per reliable sources.

metadata.background_info:
From Wikipedia,
Before, during, and after Election Day, Trump and numerous Republicans attempted to subvert the [2020 election] and overturn the results, falsely alleging that there had been widespread voter fraud, and trying to influence the vote counting process in swing states. Officials in each of the 50 states stated that there was no evidence of systematic fraud or irregularities in their state. Federal agencies overseeing election security said it was "the most secure in American history." Attorney General Bill Barr concluded there was "no evidence of widespread fraud" in the election. On multiple occasions, Trump falsely declared himself the winner. The Trump campaign and its allies continued to engage in numerous attempts to overturn the results of the election by filing dozens of legal challenges in several states, most of which were dropped or dismissed by various courts, spreading conspiracy theories falsely alleging fraud, pressuring Republican state electors and legislators, and initially refusing to cooperate with the presidential transition.

Q.title: Will there be fewer than 6 conservative justices on the SCOTUS on January 20, 2025?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if on January 20, 2025, at noon EST, there are fewer than 6 conservative justices on the Supreme Court of the United States, as per reliable sources

metadata.background_info: Define a conservative Supreme Court of the United States justice as a justice appointed by a Republican president. As of January 14th 2021, there are 6 conservative Supreme Court justices: John Roberts, Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito, Neil Gorsuch, Brett Kavanaugh, and Amy Coney Barrett.

reasons: The outcome of the presidential election and the perception of its legitimacy could influence the political climate and decisions regarding the Supreme Court. For example, if the election is considered fraudulent by the losing party, it might lead to increased political pressure or actions that could affect the composition of the Supreme Court.

The number of conservative justices on the Supreme Court could impact decisions on election-related cases, which might influence whether the losing party considers the election fraudulent. For instance, if the Court has fewer conservative justices, it might be perceived as less likely to rule in favor of conservative claims of election fraud.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as the political dynamics surrounding the election and the Supreme Court could be interrelated.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
R is the logical conjunction of P and Q because R will be true if and only if both P and Q are true. Specifically, R states that both the next US presidential election will be considered fraudulent by the losing party (P) and there will be fewer than 6 conservative justices on the SCOTUS on January 20, 2025 (Q).
Or reasoning:
R is a logical disjunction of P and Q because R will be true if either P or Q is true. P is about the next US presidential election being considered fraudulent by the losing party, and Q is about there being fewer than 6 conservative justices on the SCOTUS on January 20, 2025. R combines both conditions and will resolve positively if either of the conditions in P or Q is met.

P.title: Will global oil consumption over the 2020-2025 period be lower than in 2019?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if no year from 2020-2025 (inclusive) has greater global oil consumption than 2019 according to the EIA.
It will resolve negatively if any of those 6 years has greater consumption. It will resolve ambiguous if the EIA does not post consumption data for 2025 by the end of 2026, and no comparably authoritative source can be found (for which that source's 2019 data would be necessary)

Q.title: In 2024 or 2025, will a dispute which determines the outcome of the 2024 US Presidential Election be decided by the US Supreme Court?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if, in 2024 or 2025, a case relating to the 2024 US Presidential Election is heard and decided by the US Supreme Court which, if decided differently, would lead to different individuals being made US president.
This should exclude cases being brought before the Supreme Court which are unrelated to the 2024 election, for example a case related to impeachment of a president, or a case related to the invocation of the 25th amendment.
At least three credible media reports from different sources should be used to determine if deciding the case differently would influence the outcome of the election

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Global oil consumption over the 2020-2025 period be lower than in 2019 and (b) A dispute determining the outcome of the 2024 US Presidential Election be decided by the US Supreme Court?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following occur:

It will resolve ambiguous if the EIA does not post consumption data for 2025 by the end of 2026, and no comparably authoritative source can be found (for which that source's 2019 data would be necessary).
(b) In 2024 or 2025, a case relating to the 2024 US Presidential Election is heard and decided by the US Supreme Court which, if decided differently, would lead to different individuals being made US president. This should exclude cases being brought before the Supreme Court which are unrelated to the 2024 election, for example a case related to impeachment of a president, or a case related to the invocation of the 25th amendment. At least three credible media reports from different sources should be used to determine if deciding the case differently would influence the outcome of the election.

metadata.background_info:
Pre-covid, several forecasters expected peak oil consumption to be in the 2020s. Now, in light of plummeting 2020 consumption, several energy forecasters have concluded that perhaps the peak was 2019.
According to the EIA, 2019 usage was 100.87 mb/day (under total world consumption of petroleum and other liquids).

Q.title: In 2024 or 2025, will a dispute which determines the outcome of the 2024 US Presidential Election be decided by the US Supreme Court?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if, in 2024 or 2025, a case relating to the 2024 US Presidential Election is heard and decided by the US Supreme Court which, if decided differently, would lead to different individuals being made US president.
This should exclude cases being brought before the Supreme Court which are unrelated to the 2024 election, for example a case related to impeachment of a president, or a case related to the invocation of the 25th amendment.
At least three credible media reports from different sources should be used to determine if deciding the case differently would influence the outcome of the election

metadata.background_info:
In 2000, the 5-4 decision by the US Supreme Court in Bush v Gore was widely considered to have decided the outcome of the US election. In 2020, there were numerous attempts (e.g. here and here) to bring cases regarding the election before the Supreme Court, but all were denied.
This question asks if the Supreme Court will hear and decide a case in 2024 or 2025 which has the potential to overturn the election results.

reasons: A significant geopolitical event, such as a disputed US Presidential Election decided by the Supreme Court, could lead to political instability. This instability might affect global markets, including oil consumption.

Changes in US energy policy resulting from a new administration could impact global oil consumption. For example, a new administration might implement policies that either increase or decrease oil consumption.
A Supreme Court decision that determines the outcome of the election could lead to changes in international relations, which might affect global oil trade and consumption patterns.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as political events in the US can have significant impacts on global markets, including oil consumption.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
R is a conjunction of P and Q because it requires both conditions from P and Q to be true for R to be true. Specifically, R will resolve as Yes only if both global oil consumption over the 2020-2025 period is lower than in 2019 (P) and a dispute determining the outcome of the 2024 US Presidential Election is decided by the US Supreme Court (Q).
Or reasoning:
R is a logical disjunction of P and Q because it will resolve as Yes if either P or Q is true. P is about global oil consumption being lower than in 2019, and Q is about a dispute determining the outcome of the 2024 US Presidential Election being decided by the US Supreme Court. R combines both conditions and will resolve as Yes if either condition is met.

P.title: Will the United States land humans on the moon again before 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a mission of the United States, or any corporation incorporated in the United States, lands one or more living humans on the Moon at any time between January 1, 2019 to January 1, 2025.
The crewed landing must occur before 00:00 UTC on January 1, 2025, and at least one crew member must be a human alive at the time of landing. A successful return to Earth or any other conclusion of the mission is not necessary for a positive resolution.
A positive resolution requires that the mission is more than 50% funded by the Federal Government of the United States or by any agency thereof, or by any agency of the several States, or by any legal or natural person(s) resident (or incorporated) in the United States, or by any combination of the aforementioned entities.
A mission in which such entities contribute exactly 50% or less than 50% of the funding does not count as a US mission for the purposes of this question

metadata.background_info:
On March 26 2019, Vice President of the United States Mike Pence announced that it was the policy of the United States Government to land Americans on the moon within five years 'by any means necessary.'
Announcing the goal at a meeting of the National Space Council, Pence dismissed the goal of achieving a human landing by 2028 as 'just not good enough,' urging NASA to achieve the goal four years earlier, claiming 'we're better than that.'

Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolves Yes if one of these individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024:
Donald Trump
Donald Trump Jr.
Eric Trump
Ivanka Trump
Tiffany Trump
Melania Trump
Barron Trump

metadata.background_info:
Donald John Trump is the 45th and current president of the United States. Before entering politics, he was a businessman and television personality. Trump won a surprise victory in the 2016 presidential election, and sought re-election in the 2020 presidential election.
The Trump family has a net worth reported to be in the single-digit billions, and is now one of the most prominent families in Republican politics. Trump has several adult children, and there is speculation that a Trump political dynasty may emerge in the coming years, with both Donald Trump Jr. and Ivanka Trump suggested as possible contenders for the presidency.

reasons: Political leadership can influence space policy and funding. If a member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee, it could impact NASA's budget and priorities, potentially affecting the likelihood of a moon landing.

The Trump administration had a focus on space exploration, including the Artemis program aimed at returning humans to the moon. A Trump family member as the nominee might continue this focus, increasing the chances of a moon landing before 2025.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, particularly due to the potential influence of political leadership on space policy and funding.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
The event described in R is the conjunction of the events described in P and Q. R will resolve as Yes if both P and Q resolve as Yes, which means R is true if and only if both P and Q are true.
Or reasoning:
R is a logical disjunction of P and Q because R will resolve as Yes if either P or Q resolves as Yes. P is about the US landing humans on the moon before 2025, and Q is about a member of the Trump family being the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024. R combines both conditions and will resolve as Yes if either condition is met.

P.title: Will there be a major nuclear accident before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if an event or series of events that begins between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030 is classified as a level seven Major Accident on the INES scale (with that classification being issued before January 1, 2031), by any of the following: a national nuclear regulatory authority (for example, any of the agencies featured on this list or this list), the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, the International Atomic Energy Agency, the Head of State or Head of Government of the country in which the incident takes place, or any Permanent Member of the United Nations Security Council

Q.title: Will US Non-Overseas Contingency operations military deaths exceed 3,000 in any calendar year before 2032?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the number of military deaths across all branches of the US armed forces is greater than 3,000 in any calendar year between 2019 and 2031 (inclusive), according to the Congressional Research Service. Deaths should include all branches of the US armed forces and all active duty troops, including mobilized Reserve and Guard components. The estimate should include only "Non-Overseas Contingency Operations". Contingency Operations are defined by CRS according to
Section 101 of Title 10, United States Code, defines a contingency operation as any Secretary of Defense-designated military operation “in which members of the armed forces are or may become involved in military actions, operations, or hostilities against an enemy of the United States or against an opposing military force.
If data by CRS is not available or complete between 2019 and 2031, Metaculus may select another credible source of data, or resolve as Ambiguous at their discretion

metadata.background_info:
Related questions on Metaculus:
Will there be a major nuclear or radiological accident before 1 January 2022?
The International Nuclear and Radiological Event Scale (INES) was introduced in 1990 by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) in order to enable prompt communication of safety-significant information in case of nuclear accidents.
The scale is intended to be logarithmic, similar to the moment magnitude scale that is used to describe the comparative magnitude of earthquakes. Each increasing level represents an accident approximately ten times more severe than the previous level.
Compared to earthquakes, where the event intensity can be quantitatively evaluated, the level of severity of a man-made disaster, such as a nuclear accident, is more subject to interpretation. Because of the difficulty of interpreting, the INES level of an incident is assigned well after the incident occurs.
The INES scale consists of eight levels, with level seven - 'Major Accidents' - being the most serious. A level seven event involves a major release of radioactive material with widespread health and environmental effects requiring implementation of planned and extended countermeasures.
To date, there have been two level seven Major Accidents: the Chernobyl disaster that began on 26 April 1986, and the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster, a series of events beginning on 11 March 2011.
As INES ratings are not assigned by a central body, high-profile nuclear incidents are sometimes assigned INES ratings by the operator, by the formal body of the country, but also by scientific institutes, international authorities or other experts which may lead to confusion as to the actual severity.

According to USNI News reporting on the May 20, 2019 Congressional Research Service report:
Since 2006—five years after the start of major combat operations in Afghanistan and three years after the U.S.-led invasion of Iraq—a total of 16,652 active-duty personnel and mobilized reservists have died while serving in the U.S. Armed Forces. Seventy-three percent of these casualties occurred under circumstances unrelated to war, a category classified in this report as Non-Overseas Contingency Operations, or Non-OCO. Twenty-seven percent have died while serving in OCO operations—primarily within the territory of Iraq and Afghanistan—during periods of active combat operations. OCO operations related to Afghanistan primarily include Enduring Freedom and Freedom’s Sentinel. For Iraq, OCO operations include Iraqi Freedom, New Dawn, and Inherent Resolve. Figure 1 summarizes all service deaths since 2006.

reasons: A major nuclear accident could lead to geopolitical instability, which might increase the likelihood of military conflicts or operations that result in higher military deaths.
A major nuclear accident might lead to increased military deployments for disaster response, which could indirectly affect military death rates.
Both events are rare and catastrophic, and understanding their joint probability could be of interest to risk analysts and policymakers.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, especially from a risk analysis and geopolitical stability perspective.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
R is the logical conjunction of P and Q because R will resolve as Yes if and only if both P and Q resolve as Yes. Specifically, R requires both a major nuclear accident before 2030 (P) and US Non-Overseas Contingency operations military deaths exceeding 3,000 in any calendar year before 2032 (Q) to occur.
Or reasoning:
R is a logical disjunction of P and Q because R will resolve as Yes if either P or Q is true. Specifically, R will resolve as Yes if there is a major nuclear accident before 2030 (P) or if US Non-Overseas Contingency operations military deaths exceed 3,000 in any calendar year before 2032 (Q).

Q.title: Will humanity (essentially) run out of at least one element currently considered "under serious threat" by 2040?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
In 2008, science fiction author, Robert Silverberg, penned a provocative web essay, The Death of Galium, that predicted that we would collectively run out of several essential, rare elements within a single decade. Per Silverberg:
The element gallium is in very short supply and the world may well run out of it in just a few years. Indium is threatened too, says Armin Reller, a materials chemist at Germany’s University of Augsburg. He estimates that our planet’s stock of indium will last no more than another decade. All the hafnium will be gone by 2017 also, and another twenty years will see the extinction of zinc. Even copper is an endangered item, since worldwide demand for it is likely to exceed available supplies by the end of the present century.
Silverberg's dire fears have not (yet!) come to pass, but the American Chemical Society (ACS) has identified 44 elements that "face supply limitations in the coming years." Those considered by the ACS "under serious threat" over the next century include: silver, zinc, hafnium, gallium and helium.
It sounds serious. But not everyone is concerned. This counterpoint editorial from The Register, for instance, maintains that the galium shortage is a nothingburger:
We mine for aluminium by sticking bauxite into a Bayer Process plant, where we boil it in caustic soda. If you put the right doohicky on the side of this plant then you get the gallium out. It's at about 100ppm, 100 grammes per tonne of bauxite processed... there's around a 1,000-year supply of Ga in the bauxite that we already know that we'll process for the aluminium content... We simply don't have any meaningful shortage of these metals [worth] worrying about.
As a proxy for supply issues, we will use price. The question resolve positive if by beginning of 2040 any of the following "under serious threat" elements has a trackable commodities price that attains an inflation-adjusted price more than 10 times its price as of July 10, 2018, as measured by a reliable entity, like USGS. The elements in question are: He, Zn, Ga, Ge, As, Ag, In, Te and Hf.

P.title: Will the richest person in the world in 2033 have a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Data for resolution shall be taken from the 2033 Forbes Billionaires list (note: of course the link currently does not lead to the 2033 list). Note that this list is to be differentiated from the real time list.

metadata.background_info:
John D. Rockefeller is considered to be the wealthiest American of all time. In 1913 he was the world's richest person with a net worth of over a billion dollars. That was equivalent to about 2% of the United States' GDP back then. For reference, 2% of US GDP would be close to 400 billion dollars today! This reference perspective makes him much richer than the current richest person in the world, Jeff Bezos, whose net worth is at 112 billion dollars in the 2018 Forbes ranking.
Yet, inequality is on the rise in many developed countries and the net worth of the richest person in the world has been consistently increasing over the last few years. Could a person as rich as John D. Rockefeller reappear in the modern world?

Q.body:

reasons: The net worth of the richest person in the world could be influenced by the availability and price of essential elements. If humanity runs out of a critical element, it could disrupt industries, affect economic stability, and potentially impact the wealth of top billionaires.

Technological advancements or shortages in essential elements could drive innovation or scarcity, affecting both the economy and individual wealth accumulation. For example, a shortage in gallium could impact the tech industry, which in turn could affect the net worth of tech billionaires.

Both questions touch on broader themes of resource scarcity and economic concentration, which are interconnected in the global economy. Understanding the relationship between resource availability and wealth concentration could provide insights into future economic trends.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is worth considering as they both relate to broader economic and resource trends that could influence each other.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
R is a logical conjunction of P and Q because it combines both conditions: the richest person in the world in 2033 having a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time (P) and humanity running out of at least one element currently considered 'under serious threat' by 2040 (Q).
Or reasoning:
R is a logical disjunction of P and Q because R is true if either P or Q is true. P is about the richest person in the world in 2033 having a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time, and Q is about humanity running out of at least one element currently considered 'under serious threat' by 2040. R combines both conditions, stating that it will be true if either of the two conditions (P or Q) is true.

P.title: Will the United States continue to be among the 20 countries with the largest deterioration in state stability over the 2019-2029 period, according to the Fragile States Index?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The Fragile State Index is an important metric of government stability. It is published every year here.
According to the 2019 report (see page 11), over the 2009 to 2019 period, The US was #12 among the countries with the most rapidly deteriorating Fragile States Index. The US was still among the more stable nations in the world but the trend was clearly in the direction of less stability.
Will the United States continue to be among the 20 countries with the largest deterioration in state stability over the 2019-2029 period, according to the Fragile States Index?
This question resolves positively if the United States is amongst the 20 countries with the largest long-term increase (worsening) of fragile state score over the 2019-2029 period.
If for some reason, Fund for Peace ceases to publish this index, or their index can no longer be compared historically this question will be ambiguous, unless the Fund For Peace designates a successor index that also shows which 20 countries have deteriorated the most over the period 2019 to 2029 from a standpoint of stability.
If the United States ceases to exist as a unified nation this question resolves positive.

Q.title: If there's a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, will this cause >400 million fatalities?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question conditions on there being a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, using the same specification as in a previous question (except that here the year 2030 is used instead of 2024[1]). That is, the question resolves ambiguously if that condition isn't met. As noted in that previous question, this could be caused either by nuclear conflict or by something else.
The question resolves positively if:
The above condition is met
At least three credible sources state or estimate that, within 5 years of the end of the year in which the first 10% shortfall by 2030 occurs, more than 400 million fatalities were caused by that shortfall.
For example, if the shortfall occurs in 2027, this question is about whether that causes >400m fatalities by the end of 2032.
If a source gives a range as its estimate, the midpoint of that range will be used as its estimate.
See also:
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >1m fatalities within 1 month of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >100m fatalities within 1 month of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >1b fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations cause >4b fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation?
Fine Print
For simplicity, no attempt will be made to second-guess credible sources on what fatalities should be considered to be "caused" by the 10% shortfall. For example, if the 10% shortfall is followed by armed conflict, no attempt will be made to second-guess what credible sources say about whether the fatalities caused by that armed conflict should be considered to be ultimately caused by the 10% shortfall.
[1] The reason for using 2030 rather than 2024 for this question is that the fatalities and discussion of them may occur on a several-year delay from the actual shortfall. It therefore seemed unwise to force this question to resolve by 2024, and hence best to make this part of the long-term rather than calibration tournament.

P_and_Q.title: Will the United States be among the 20 countries with the largest deterioration in state stability over 2019-2029 and will a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030 cause >400 million fatalities?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria:

1. The United States must be among the 20 countries with the largest deterioration in state stability over the 2019-2029 period, according to the Fragile States Index. This question resolves positively if the United States is amongst the 20 countries with the largest long-term increase (worsening) of fragile state score over the 2019-2029 period. If the Fund for Peace ceases to publish this index, or their index can no longer be compared historically, this question will be ambiguous unless a successor index is designated. If the United States ceases to exist as a unified nation, this question resolves positively.

2. There must be a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, and this shortfall must cause more than 400 million fatalities within 5 years of the end of the year in which the shortfall occurs. This question resolves positively if at least three credible sources state or estimate that more than 400 million fatalities were caused by the shortfall. If a source gives a range as its estimate, the midpoint of that range will be used as its estimate.

Both conditions must be met for this combined question to resolve positively.

metadata.background_info:
Another question in this tournament asks Will there be a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2024?.
Denkenberger & Pearce (2016) write:
"The uncertainty in the number of fatalities due to a 10% agricultural shortfall is very large. On the optimistic extreme, there could be aggressive government support or charity such that the vast majority of the global poor could generally afford sufficient food. If the crisis were only a year or two, loans could be feasible, either to poor individuals or poor countries. The necessary conservation (less waste, less food to animals, and so on) in the developed countries could be achieved by higher prices or rationing. However, even if mass starvation is averted, generally there would be more malnutrition and increasing susceptibility to disease. The poor would be less able to afford other lifesaving measures, and a pandemic would be more likely. Even if food aid is available, it may not be possible to get the food to the people who need it. Therefore, near zero mortality is unlikely. At the same time, even with no catastrophe, 6.5 million people die of hunger-related diseases per year (UNICEF 2006). On the other extreme, there could be food export restrictions or bans, as implemented by India, Vietnam, Egypt, and China in 2008 (Helfand 2013) when the situation was much less serious. This hoarding on a country level could also be coupled with hoarding on an individual level. This could dramatically reduce the food supply available to poor people.
Armed conflict could be in some countries’ best interest, which could also aggravate famine (Keller 1992; Waldman 2001; Goodhand 2003). These wars could even evolve into nuclear conflict, which would further impact food supplies."

reasons: A significant deterioration in state stability in the United States could have wide-ranging global impacts, including on global food security. A less stable US might be less able to contribute to global agricultural production or to international efforts to mitigate a global agricultural shortfall.

A 10% global agricultural shortfall could exacerbate existing political and social tensions within the United States, potentially contributing to further deterioration in state stability as measured by the Fragile States Index.
Both questions involve large-scale, systemic risks that could be interconnected through complex global systems, making it valuable to consider their combined probabilities.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is worth considering due to the potential interconnections between state stability and global agricultural shortfalls.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
The question R is a logical conjunction of questions P and Q. R requires both conditions from P and Q to be met for it to resolve positively. Specifically, R states that the United States must be among the 20 countries with the largest deterioration in state stability over the 2019-2029 period (condition from P) and that there must be a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030 causing more than 400 million fatalities (condition from Q). Therefore, R is true if and only if both P and Q are true.
Or reasoning:
R is a logical disjunction of P and Q because it states that either P or Q can occur for R to be true. Specifically, R will be true if either the United States continues to be among the 20 countries with the largest deterioration in state stability over the 2019-2029 period (P) or if a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030 causes more than 400 million fatalities (Q).

P.title: Will there be 10 or more nuclear-armed states at any time before 2035?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2035, at least 3 credible sources report that at least 10 countries have a deployable nuclear weapon.
Fine Print
For this question to resolve positively, it needs not be the case that there are 10 or more nuclear-armed states at the start of 2035 specifically; if one or more nuclear-armed states give up nuclear weapons by 2035, but at some point before 2035 there were at least 10 states with deployable nuclear weapons, this question would resolve positively.
If a current nuclear-armed state fractures into multiple states and more than one of the successor states then possess deployable weapons, each of those states will count as separate nuclear-armed states for the purposes of this question. (The reason for this is that the successor states will likely have substantially different geopolitical relationships and interests.)

Q.title: Will renewable energy contribute 25% or less to global electricity production in 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if renewable energy contributes 25.00% or less to global electricity production in the calendar year 2030, according to World Bank data.
Historical data can be found here. Please make a copy by clicking "file" and then "make a copy" if you wish to edit it. If you make useful additions to the dataset, please share the file in the comments

P_and_Q.title: Will there be 10 or more nuclear-armed states at any time before 2035 and will renewable energy contribute 25% or less to global electricity production in 2030?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met:
(a) At any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2035, at least 3 credible sources report that at least 10 countries have a deployable nuclear weapon.
(b) Renewable energy contributes 25.00% or less to global electricity production in the calendar year 2030, according to World Bank data.

Fine Print
For condition (a) to resolve positively, it needs not be the case that there are 10 or more nuclear-armed states at the start of 2035 specifically; if one or more nuclear-armed states give up nuclear weapons by 2035, but at some point before 2035 there were at least 10 states with deployable nuclear weapons, this condition would resolve positively.
If a current nuclear-armed state fractures into multiple states and more than one of the successor states then possess deployable weapons, each of those states will count as separate nuclear-armed states for the purposes of this condition. (The reason for this is that the successor states will likely have substantially different geopolitical relationships and interests.)

Historical data for condition (b) can be found here. Please make a copy by clicking "file" and then "make a copy" if you wish to edit it. If you make useful additions to the dataset, please share the file in the comments.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) There be 10 or more nuclear-armed states at any time before 2035? (b) Renewable energy contribute 25% or less to global electricity production in 2030?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
(a) This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2035, at least 3 credible sources report that at least 10 countries have a deployable nuclear weapon.
Fine Print
For this question to resolve positively, it needs not be the case that there are 10 or more nuclear-armed states at the start of 2035 specifically; if one or more nuclear-armed states give up nuclear weapons by 2035, but at some point before 2035 there were at least 10 states with deployable nuclear weapons, this question would resolve positively.
If a current nuclear-armed state fractures into multiple states and more than one of the successor states then possess deployable weapons, each of those states will count as separate nuclear-armed states for the purposes of this question. (The reason for this is that the successor states will likely have substantially different geopolitical relationships and interests.)
(b) This question will resolve as Yes if renewable energy contributes 25.00% or less to global electricity production in the calendar year 2030, according to World Bank data.
Historical data can be found here. Please make a copy by clicking "file" and then "make a copy" if you wish to edit it. If you make useful additions to the dataset, please share the file in the comments

P.title: Will there be 10 or more nuclear-armed states at any time before 2035?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2035, at least 3 credible sources report that at least 10 countries have a deployable nuclear weapon.
Fine Print
For this question to resolve positively, it needs not be the case that there are 10 or more nuclear-armed states at the start of 2035 specifically; if one or more nuclear-armed states give up nuclear weapons by 2035, but at some point before 2035 there were at least 10 states with deployable nuclear weapons, this question would resolve positively.
If a current nuclear-armed state fractures into multiple states and more than one of the successor states then possess deployable weapons, each of those states will count as separate nuclear-armed states for the purposes of this question. (The reason for this is that the successor states will likely have substantially different geopolitical relationships and interests.)

metadata.background_info:
As of 2021, nine states possess nuclear weapons: Russia, US, China, France, UK, Pakistan, India, Israel, and North Korea. The most recent entrant into that nuclear club was North Korea, in 2006.
A few other states possessed nuclear weapons in the past but no longer do: in particular, some former Soviet republics gave up their inherited nuclear weapons after the Soviet Union collapsed, and South Africa built nuclear weapons but then dismantled them in 1991.
Other states have secretly explored nuclear weapon development or have been found in violation of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. Some countries have more Breakout Capability than others-- both Japan and Iran have sufficient uranium and other resources to quickly develop nuclear weapons.

Q.title: Will renewable energy contribute 25% or less to global electricity production in 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if renewable energy contributes 25.00% or less to global electricity production in the calendar year 2030, according to World Bank data.
Historical data can be found here. Please make a copy by clicking "file" and then "make a copy" if you wish to edit it. If you make useful additions to the dataset, please share the file in the comments

metadata.background_info:
The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has outlined various illustrative model pathways for limiting global warming to 1.5°C by the end of the century. Its fourth pathway (P4) is the worst-case scenario in terms of our ability to transition our energy supply toward renewables. In this scenario, the only way to limit global warming to 1.5°C is by making strong use of carbon dioxide removal (CDR) techniques, such as through the deployment of Bio-energy with carbon capture and storage (BECCS). According the (IPCC, 2018):
P4: A resource- and energy-intensive scenario in which economic growth and globalization lead to widespread adoption of greenhouse-gas-intensive lifestyles, including high demand for transportation fuels and livestock products. Emissions reductions are mainly achieved through technological means, making strong use of CDR through the deployment of BECCS.
According to the (IPCC, 2018), P4 is consistent with a share of 25% or less of renewables energy used in electricity production in 2030.
In 2016, 22.66% of total electricity was produced using renewable energy, according to World Bank data.

reasons: Geopolitical instability: An increase in the number of nuclear-armed states could lead to greater geopolitical instability, which might affect global energy policies and investments in renewable energy.
Resource allocation: Countries investing heavily in nuclear arms might allocate fewer resources to renewable energy development, potentially affecting global renewable energy contributions.
Global priorities: A world with more nuclear-armed states might prioritize security and defense over environmental concerns, impacting renewable energy targets.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as geopolitical and resource allocation factors could link nuclear proliferation and renewable energy contributions.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
R is the logical conjunction of P and Q because R will resolve as Yes only if both P and Q resolve as Yes. Specifically, R requires that there be 10 or more nuclear-armed states at any time before 2035 (condition (a) from P) and that renewable energy contributes 25% or less to global electricity production in 2030 (condition (b) from Q).
Or reasoning:
R is a logical disjunction of P and Q because R will resolve as Yes if either P or Q resolves as Yes. P and Q are independent events, and R covers both scenarios, making it a valid disjunction.

P.title: Will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
There is said to be an "AI Sputnik moment" if ANY of the following come true before 2050,
A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system. Upon the announcement, their stock price skyrockets by over 100% compared to its previous value within 7 days, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock price is likely a result of the AI development.
News of an AI development triggers the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP nominal to give a public speech regarding the ramifications of this particular AI development, within two weeks of the initial news reports.
The Nasdaq Composite (which is currently heavily weighted towards companies in the information technology sector) rises over 30% in the course of a single week, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock prices is likely a result of the AI development.
The Google Trends monitor for artificial intelligence shows that interest in artificial intelligence rises by over 100% relative to of its previous value, compared to the week prior (using the resolution at 12 months, as currently displayed by the Google Trends widget). If Google Trends changes their functionality or methodology dramatically (as determined by Metaculus admins), then this condition can no longer trigger a positive resolution.
Practically all reliable media outlets are referring to an AI development as an AI Sputnik moment, as referring to the historical Sputnik 1 satellite
Fine Print
Google Trends index scores vary depending on the date and location from which a user checks the site. To reduce ambiguity, to trigger the Google Trends section of the resolution criteria:
At least two Metaculus administrators need to be able to see the >100% Google Trends increase, when checking from different locations.
The increase must remain >100% for at least four days to trigger a Yes resolution. For instance, if we first notice an increase of >100% on a Monday, we will check again on Friday. We will only resolve "Yes" if the reported increase for the weeks in question is >100% on both days we check, for both admins, and we have no evidence that it dropped below 100% at any point during those four days.

Q.title: If China invades Taiwan before 2035, will Japan respond with military forces?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
If China does not launch a full-scale invasion of Taiwan before January 1, 2035, then this question will resolve as Ambiguous. If China does invade Taiwan, this question will resolve as Yes if Japan responds with military forces within 365 days from of the beginning of the Chinese invasion.
In line with our main question, China will be considered to have launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan if either of these occur:
The Associated Press and the New York Times both report that the People's Republic of China has launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan.
At least 1,000 military personnel from the People's Liberation Army have been deployed to Taiwan for the purpose of putting the sovereignty of the main island under PRC rule.
Japan will be considered to have responded with military forces if there is an offensive physical attack on Chinese infrastructure, ships, military personnel, or civilians, in direct retaliation to the full-scale invasion, and this attack is ordered by the Japanese government or Japanese military leadership. Cyberattacks will not be considered offensive physical attacks, but covert operations to e.g. assassinate Chinese nationals, will count

We will only resolve "Yes" if the reported increase for the weeks in question is >100% on both days we check, for both admins, and we have no evidence that it dropped below 100% at any point during those four days.

2. If China invades Taiwan before January 1, 2035, Japan responds with military forces. In line with our main question, China will be considered to have launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan if either of these occur:

Japan will be considered to have responded with military forces if there is an offensive physical attack on Chinese infrastructure, ships, military personnel, or civilians, in direct retaliation to the full-scale invasion, and this attack is ordered by the Japanese government or Japanese military leadership. Cyberattacks will not be considered offensive physical attacks, but covert operations to e.g. assassinate Chinese nationals, will count.

metadata.background_info:
From Wikipedia,
Sputnik 1 was the first artificial Earth satellite. It was launched into an elliptical low Earth orbit by the USSR on 4 October 1957 as part of the Soviet space program. It orbited for three weeks before its batteries died and then orbited silently for two months before it fell back into the atmosphere on the 4th January 1958.
[...]
The satellite's unanticipated success precipitated the American Sputnik crisis and triggered the Space Race, part of the Cold War. The launch was the beginning of a new era of political, military, technological and scientific developments.
An "AI Sputnik moment" would, by contrast, be a sudden understanding by the general public that artificial intelligence is worth taking extremely seriously, perhaps triggering a similar AI arms race.

Q.title: If China invades Taiwan before 2035, will Japan respond with military forces?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
If China does not launch a full-scale invasion of Taiwan before January 1, 2035, then this question will resolve as Ambiguous. If China does invade Taiwan, this question will resolve as Yes if Japan responds with military forces within 365 days from of the beginning of the Chinese invasion.
In line with our main question, China will be considered to have launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan if either of these occur:
The Associated Press and the New York Times both report that the People's Republic of China has launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan.
At least 1,000 military personnel from the People's Liberation Army have been deployed to Taiwan for the purpose of putting the sovereignty of the main island under PRC rule.
Japan will be considered to have responded with military forces if there is an offensive physical attack on Chinese infrastructure, ships, military personnel, or civilians, in direct retaliation to the full-scale invasion, and this attack is ordered by the Japanese government or Japanese military leadership. Cyberattacks will not be considered offensive physical attacks, but covert operations to e.g. assassinate Chinese nationals, will count

metadata.background_info:
Related questions on Metaculus:
Will China launch a full-scale invasion of Taiwan by the following years?
If China invades Taiwan before 2035, will the US respond with military forces?
With tensions in the Taiwan Strait at a boiling point, it has been reported that Japan is considering becoming militarily involved if an armed conflict breaks out in the region. This is notable as Japan has not fought in any wars since the end of World War 2.
This question asks: will Japan fight on Taiwan's side if Taiwan is invaded by China?

reasons: An AI Sputnik moment could significantly alter global power dynamics, potentially influencing geopolitical decisions, including military responses.
Technological advancements in AI could lead to new military technologies or strategies, which might affect Japan's decision-making in a conflict scenario.
Economic impacts of an AI Sputnik moment could influence national budgets and priorities, including military spending and readiness.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as technological and geopolitical developments can be interconnected.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
The event described in R is the conjunction of the events described in P and Q. Specifically, R will be true if and only if both an AI Sputnik moment occurs before 2050 (P) and, if China invades Taiwan before 2035, Japan responds with military forces (Q). This matches the logical conjunction definition, where R is true if and only if both P and Q are true.
Or reasoning:
R is a logical disjunction of P and Q because R will be true if either P or Q is true. P is about an AI Sputnik moment before 2050, and Q is about Japan responding with military forces if China invades Taiwan before 2035. R combines both conditions, stating that it will be true if either an AI Sputnik moment occurs before 2050 or Japan responds with military forces if China invades Taiwan before 2035.

P.title: Will Xi Jinping continue leading China in 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positive if either:
Xi is CCP General Secretary on 1 January, 2030.
Xi is paramount leader of China on 1 January, 2030.
Xi is de facto leader of China on 1 January, 2030.
This question will resolve negative if:
Any other person is leader on 1 January, 2030.
This question will resolve ambiguous if:
China ceases to exist as the political entity it is right now

Q.title: If human-level artificial intelligence is developed, will World GDP grow by at least 30.0% in any of the subsequent 15 years?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
If a machine passes the test in this Metaculus question, this question resolves as YES if world GDP grows by at least 30.0% for any single year in the fifteen years following the date of the test, according to a reputable organization such as The World Bank, and NO if it doesn't.
If no machine passes that test by 2100-01-01, then this question resolves ambiguously.

P_and_Q.title: Will Xi Jinping continue leading China in 2030 and, if human-level artificial intelligence is developed, will World GDP grow by at least 30.0% in any of the subsequent 15 years?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positive if both of the following conditions are met:
1. Either:
  a. Xi is CCP General Secretary on 1 January, 2030.
  b. Xi is paramount leader of China on 1 January, 2030.
  c. Xi is de facto leader of China on 1 January, 2030.
2. If a machine passes the test in this Metaculus question, world GDP grows by at least 30.0% for any single year in the fifteen years following the date of the test, according to a reputable organization such as The World Bank.

This question will resolve negative if any of the following conditions are met:
1. Any other person is leader on 1 January, 2030.
2. If a machine passes the test in this Metaculus question, world GDP does not grow by at least 30.0% for any single year in the fifteen years following the date of the test, according to a reputable organization such as The World Bank.

This question will resolve ambiguous if any of the following conditions are met:
1. China ceases to exist as the political entity it is right now.
2. No machine passes the test in the Metaculus question by 2100-01-01.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Xi Jinping continues leading China in 2030 (b) If human-level artificial intelligence is developed, World GDP grows by at least 30.0% in any of the subsequent 15 years?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if either of the following occurs:
(a) Xi is CCP General Secretary on 1 January, 2030, or Xi is paramount leader of China on 1 January, 2030, or Xi is de facto leader of China on 1 January, 2030.
(b) If a machine passes the test in this Metaculus question, world GDP grows by at least 30.0% for any single year in the fifteen years following the date of the test, according to a reputable organization such as The World Bank.

This question will resolve as NO if neither of the above occurs.

This question will resolve as ambiguous if either of the following occurs:
(a) China ceases to exist as the political entity it is right now.
(b) No machine passes the test in the Metaculus question by 2100-01-01.

P.title: Will Xi Jinping continue leading China in 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positive if either:
Xi is CCP General Secretary on 1 January, 2030.
Xi is paramount leader of China on 1 January, 2030.
Xi is de facto leader of China on 1 January, 2030.
This question will resolve negative if:
Any other person is leader on 1 January, 2030.
This question will resolve ambiguous if:
China ceases to exist as the political entity it is right now

metadata.background_info: Xi Jinping is currently nearing the end of his second term as CCP General Secretary and is expected to make a bid for a third term and win it with a 92% chance according to a current Metaculus question. There is considerable speculation that Xi will pave the way for a much longer tenure akin to the tenure of Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaping. Having China ruled by a single figure with a potentially unlimited tenure might have considerable ramifications for a variety of topics ranging from the West's China policy to global security concerns.

Q.title: If human-level artificial intelligence is developed, will World GDP grow by at least 30.0% in any of the subsequent 15 years?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
If a machine passes the test in this Metaculus question, this question resolves as YES if world GDP grows by at least 30.0% for any single year in the fifteen years following the date of the test, according to a reputable organization such as The World Bank, and NO if it doesn't.
If no machine passes that test by 2100-01-01, then this question resolves ambiguously.

metadata.background_info:
In economist Robin Hanson's 2001 paper Economic Growth Given Machine Intelligence, he writes
A simple exogenous growth model gives conservative estimates of the economic implications of machine intelligence. [...] Without machine intelligence, world product grows at a familiar rate of 4.3% per year, doubling every 16 years, with about 40% of technological progress coming from ordinary computers. With machine intelligence, the (instantaneous) annual growth rate would be 45%, ten times higher, making world product double every 18 months! If the product shares are raised by 20%, and general technology growth is lowered to preserve the 4.4% figure, the new doubling time falls to less than 6 months.

reasons: Xi Jinping's leadership could influence China's policies on AI development, which in turn could impact global AI advancements.
China's economic policies under Xi Jinping could affect global economic conditions, potentially influencing the likelihood of achieving human-level AI and subsequent economic growth.
Xi Jinping's leadership might affect international relations and collaborations in AI research, which could impact the development and deployment of human-level AI.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as Xi Jinping's leadership could have significant implications for AI development and global economic growth.

verification_result.reasoning:
And reasoning:
R is a logical conjunction of P and Q because R will resolve positive only if both P and Q resolve positive. Specifically, R requires both Xi Jinping to continue leading China in 2030 and, if human-level AI is developed, for the world GDP to grow by at least 30.0% in any of the subsequent 15 years. The resolution criteria for R are a combination of the criteria for P and Q.
Or reasoning:
R is the logical disjunction of P and Q because R will resolve as YES if either P or Q is true. Specifically, R will resolve as YES if either Xi Jinping continues leading China in 2030 (P) or if human-level artificial intelligence is developed and World GDP grows by at least 30.0% in any of the subsequent 15 years (Q).
